summary: Meg Murry and her little brother, Charles Wallace, have been without their scientist father, Mr. Murry, for five years, ever since he discovered a new planet and used the concept known as a tesseract to travel there. Joined by Meg's classmate Calvin O'Keefe and guided by the three mysterious astral travelers known as Mrs. Whatsit, Mrs. Who and Mrs. Which, the children brave a dangerous journey to a planet that possesses all of the evil in the universe.

reviews.content: It was very unique that makes you say spectacular and very peculiar
characters=4/5 plot=3.5/5 acting=3/5 songs =5/5 movie vibe=2.5/5 ending=4/5

5 years later this ends being pretty misguided but relatively harmless The plot is notoriously difficult to explain being it's based on the book by Madeleine L'Engle Director Ava Duvernay helms a large cast starring Storm Reid, Reese Witherspoon, Oprah Winfrey, Mindy Kaling, Chris Pine, Gugu Mbatha-Raw, Zach Galafanakis, Michael Pena, and Rowan Blanchard in fantasy/sci-fi story of family Meg's parents are eager to explore more of the universe and traveling to other parts of it; of course her father has been doubted by everyone so he decides to venture on his own tapping into the right frequency But he ends up going missing in between dimensions trying to make his discovery after a year 3 magical witches Mrs. Which, Mrs. Whatsit, and Mrs. Who then offer to take Meg, her brother, and friend Calvin to look for him and they come across other worldly things like sentient flowers, flying leaves, and an evil entity called the IT that feeds off beings' negative energy Meg has to learn to open her mind and be more trusting to herself battling her insecurities in the process The movie is good, not great, felt very rushed and a lot of those scenes in the trailer were missing I think the biggest issue is that the book is full of more Christian themes which maybe explains why this movie was so limited and they didn't want to step on anyone's toes It does have a clear cut allegory about the evils of communism and conformity But there are some effective emotional moments, interesting visuals, some interesting concepts, and it has a great slew of actors Aside from Pine and Reid who nail their roles perfectly everyone else feels like they're in a completely different movie In order to be great it's not enough to be right, finding out all the universe's secrets cannot measure how much love we have in our hearts, we don't have to be desperate to matter in the universe This movie might still stand out as one of those trippy movies kids can look back on making them think Won't hold much for adults though for all the trippyness involved I do like the fantasy element as well as the actors but the narrative is clumsy

Clearly written on drugs. Costumes are meant to be loud and stunning, but they look cheaper than the special effects. Characters lack any development and lines/script is as poor in writing as in delivery.

But their efforts would only quell the stink of a few problems with the film. It's one of those houses that needs to be completely torn down and built back up entirely different.

A young girl named Meg travels through the universe in search of her father. Based on a novel by Madeleine L'Engle that I have not yet read. Storm Reid plays the lead and I wasn't wowed by her performance, but I think she did a good job. Chris Pine and Reese Witherspoon both make good use of the limited screen time they have. There were many moments of "hey look at this CGI sequence that we bought" in this film that slowed the pacing down and took away potential character moments that this film needed more of. I was very confused by the motivation, or plan, of the villain. Through the movie I was rooting for the lead, but had no doubt she would succeed. Skip this film.

It's SO bad. Even after reading the book and understanding it, I find the movie extremely confusing and hard to follow. Several times we had to pause and be like, "Wait, what is going on now?" Characters continually compliment Meg to the point that it gets creepy. There is a weird side plot with a school bully that doesn't make much sense and could easily be eliminated. There's an awkward beach scene that comes out of nowhere and gets weird when one of the characters shows his glowing red eyes and sticks out his tongue. Reese Witherspoon turns into a giant floating leaf. Oprah spends half the time floating around as a giant in the background. There's just a lot that doesn't make sense. Also, the CGI hurts my eyes. And why are we calling It "The It" instead of just "It"? So many questions.

I absolutely cannot stand this movie. I can't find anything I liked about this film it seems like an uninspired cash grab trying to come off as imaginative and special. The characters have no depth, they just appear out of nowhere and don't do anything interesting, the plot is unoriginal and clich√© while still managing to be a mess and there are individual scenes of this movie which I cannot stand. A few parts of this movie make me laugh out loud about how terrible of a film it is and some are just plainly terrible. I'm not lying when I say this is my least favourite movie of all time.
There's no doubt in my mind that this movie looks amazing. Yet a story can't drive off of visuals.

This film belongs to the visual effects guys as it looks good with some tricky shots. The problem comes in with the conflict of camera work, atmosphere and concept design, meaning it has no clear distinction as to what it wants to be. It's filmed like a scientific drama, but tries to have a sort of magic and cosmos feel and it doesn't work because the visual lacks atmosphere and has a lot of handheld operation. To me, it feels like the director couldn't handle the weight of the project and simply tried to get the shots done in time. The hinting at technical scientific theories is weak and brushed under the carpet, even though it's for kids it still felt weak. Disney has seemed to lost their master filmmakers who were disciplined in all aspects of filmmaking. And if I have to hear the double name "Charles-Wallace" one more time I'll go crazy.
Kid's name is Charles Wallace, that tells you all you need to know about the quality of the film.

"A Wrinkle in Time" is best described as a mix bag; moments of brilliance and moments of "why was this not cut?" On one hand, this Disney adaptation has splendid color and CGI that will "wow" the kids, but on the other hand this story about two children trying to find their missing father fails to develop any of its prolific ideas or smooth out its narrative gaps.

While visually stunning, it missed the mark for me. Kids were alright, made you feel. The little Charles Wallace character is adorable. Reese, fantastic as always, and the comic relief. Mindy felt a little robotic, which is too bad because she's good. And showing the egomaniac Oprah as almost godlike..üòë..no thanks. They missed the mark on that casting call. If you're looking for something to pass the time then I'd give it a whirl, it definitely a kids movie. But don't expect too much.

I love this movie. There are people that say that you can't enjoy it unless you are a 14 year old but I am actually 20 years old. I haven't read the book, although I plan to. If you did read the book, don't expect the movie to follow it to the T. And don't be so harsh oh my God some of the reviews I see of this are so harsh. Damn! You go make a movie! lol I think the movie is beautiful. I love how it showed women of color and how the leading actress was a black girl. It talked so much about self-love, unity and peace. It has deep messages about loving and accepting who you are. It is beautiful to see how Meg has so much love for her family and keeps on following her gut and intuition despite how people don't believe in her. In situations where someone would is completely loose hope, she is persistent and resilient. I have watched this movie so many times and it brings me so much joy.

The problem in cases like this is that the indisputable nature of its message, centered on the power of love with a good dose of female empowerment, should not serve to hide a script with a clear tendency to the schematic that relies too much on the effectiveness of certain scenes is enough so that by the mere fact of putting them together, everything will fit perfectly

'A Wrinkle in Time', I think, starts off very nicely. It gives a satisfactory background to the main character, while it builds the intrigue well. Unfortunately, it does drop off as it goes on - but not to the point that it hindered my enjoyment, it is a noticeable step down though. I really like the special effects, I think they look terrific throughout.

Onto the cast. Storm Reid does a respectable job as Meg, her performance arguably gets better as things progress - which is the opposite to the film overall. Chris Pine is underused in his role, but the casting of Oprah Winfrey, Reese Witherspoon and Mindy Kaling is good - Zach Galifianakis too. I didn't actually find Deric McCabe's character, Charles Wallace, annoying like most seemingly did.

Surprised to see that this has a low rating across the board. I've never read the Madeleine L'Engle novel so perhaps that has something to do with it? I do agree the writing isn't necessarily great either. Each to the own, but I genuinely enjoyed it I can't lie.

The visuals aren't anything special and the characters are just weird.

The book is one of my all-time favorites, so I had very high expectations for this movie. It has pretty great casting in my opinion, and had amazing visuals and a really sweet clear message at it's core. But what I don't like about this movie, though, is the fact that it seems like a bit of cash grab, ya know? Like they were a little more focused on the money aspect, and less on the actual storytelling. Like, I don't like a lot of Meg's lines, or just her general vibe throughout the movie to be honest, even though the actress portraying her had so much potential. I loved the guy playing Calvin, I think he did a great job and they brought to life a very unique vision of him, which I really loved. I just wish we had more time with him, because he kind of seems like 'just along for the ride', even though he is so much deeper in the book. The only real character development we get from him is his dad, and that one line from the It. I also really loved Charles Wallace, and he's to be honest the only main character besides the Mrs', that has no actual faults. The casting was perfect, he had good dialogue, he was likable just like he was in the book. Mr and Mrs Murray were okay, I guess, we didn't get too much time with them so they don't even matter that much. Also, I think the Veronica role was just shoved in movie to make it so they have another well-known star in there. All in all, it just seems a little lazily put together, but had SO MUCH potential. I loved their take on this universe and story, it had such a unique signature to it, but with the lazy writing and some lazy shots here and there, it kind of didn't go all of the way that it needed to. I kind of wish they did, because then we get to see how they bring the rest of the series to life, which would be really cool to see. But what can I say, it's disney.

I was probably 12 when I read a Wrinkle in Time for the first time. It had a profound effect on me. 40 years later I still can't see subdivisions without thinking about the scene from the book where they are standing on the hill on Camazotz looking down at the houses and all the houses look exactly the same. Sameness became a dirty word for me. The book made me value those things that made me different. I would guess that maybe 20% of the movie comes from the book. The rest was created, written for the movie. I wanted to love the movie. But the drastic rewriting of the story made it impossible at the end. I've watched movies that had nothing to do with the original source: Robert Downing Jr. in Sherlock for instance. It has very little to do with the Conan Doyle version of Sherlock but it's fun as heck to watch. The changes made between L'Engle's book and the movie make no sense. They weaken the story. Mrs. Whatsit would never have kicked Meg in the book, why did they have her do it in the movie? Thirty minutes into the film and I found myself hating Mrs. Whatsit. At one point in the book there is an intense struggle between Charles Wallace and a certain entity, but in the movie he just instantly yields. Why? It goes against everything that Charles Wallace was/is. Over and over the movie rewrites the book to it's own detriment. By the end I was bitterly disappointed, angry, and frustrated. Loved the actors, except maybe Charles Wallace. My advice, go read the book.
Felt like the story was all over the place, fantasy nightmare.

Jeez.  Enough already.  I get the idea - women need to be empowered, and now.  But there are more subtle ways of getting this point across other than hammering your audience over their heads with a 2 X 4.  A little character development independent of this message would have done this movie a world of good.  And the plot was too contrived with so many holes that I lost track.  A pox on it.

The plot is predictable. There's no plot twist. Many questions were left unanswered. Where did the IT come from? Why was he trapped there? Does the time in the planet pass like it does on Earth? Where did the Misses come from? Why were they not able to stay longer in the IT's hideout? How did the IT persuade Charles Wallace to do what he did?

I mean I know the book's really imaginative and it may be hard to put into motion, but I mean common... I constantly get really mad at this movie

Sort of exactly what you'd expect. Sloppy, slow, muddy, lowest common denominator children's film with bad dialogue, no sense of scale and no cohesive design. I applaud the abundance of female characters in strong roles and the superb, gentle damaged soul of the beta-female Lead Character. But Duverny has no understanding of how to shoot fantasy, at first coming across awkwardly against the urban backdrop and then later in a soulless void of green screen with flat plates of actors and vistas with no grounding or relevance. Wrinkle has a stodgy  story with no relatable sense of logic; typically, although cliche, these kinds of fantasy kids films end up portraying the fantasy elements as connected to the grief or fear of the child as they grow up. This film just throws colourful nonsense at us willy billy with no explanation of the logic and no way of connecting to any of it. One imagines that if this were a 2D animated Ghibli film it would be spectacular and appropriate, but like this it ironically seems lifeless and disconnected and pointless. 
It's twists and turns are predictable and the action is turgid. The way characters meet and the plot moves on are utterly contrived, it's disappointing really. 
It's not a terrible film, and sometimes with the dramatic elements it can actually be quite stirring and emotional, it's just mostly a film that misses the mark in every department.
The rating system said it passed the time, but it felt like every frame that passed was killing a new brain cell and by the end of the movie I was a brainless husk of a person.

We honestly believe the people at Hollywood uncovered and dusted off this book, thought the title looked interesting, got the names out of the book, and made up this whole movie! It's bright and colorful, but that can't make up for lack of acting, plot, and purpose.

Closest comparison: It's a big budget Disney Channel movie.

It was one of my favorite books when I read it as an 8 year old in 1960.  It should have been made with the adjectives that described it IN the book! Too much time was spent in the beginning with SUNSHINE, and LOW KEY DELIVERY, where everyone spoke in whispers,and smiles!  IT WAS A "DARK AND STORMY NIGHT" WITH A PURPOSE!!!  Loneliness, heartbreak from the mother (from Meg hearing her cry every night), Who, Whatsit, and Which appeared at NIGHT - with the door flying open in the storm, not all "glittery and sunshine and smiles" like it's an ordinary day.  It does not have munchkins singing about the "Yellow Brick Road", and this looks like it is set up to be that way. The story has foreboding in every word Whatsit, Who and Which speak! The time should be spent when Meg tries to recover from the Tesseract, and the creatures has long arms, more like an octopus, not a green video game Princess that looks like a Sea Monkey you buy from the back of a comic!! Children express themselves with abandonment, not "whispers"!!!  UPLIFTING voices, even in fear! The director had the kids speak so monotone, it became boring very quickly! I mean, who cares about the kids before they even get to the "village"??? And, OPRAH - what happened to that great actress that had us in the palm of your hand when you were in the Color Purple?  Your delivery was so..... FLAT!!!!!  Who cares if you are "looking for a man who is lost in the universe?"  It seemed like you just wanted to go "around the corner" and you would find him! This is a story that can make you shudder, and feel some trepidation and fear, only to have such a showdown with "IT" that never materialized here! I mean, what's the matter with you, Director????  Don't YOU have the imagination and wonder and thrill of discovery that a child has???  TAKE THAT AND PUT IT OUT ON THE SCREEN!!! There should be the 'introductory scene" of the village with the children bouncing the balls in tandem, and the permeating "thud thud thud" of the rhythm of the  bouncing ball, that slowly creeps into the pulsing vein in Charles Wallace's head when he and "IT" confront the other kids!!!! THIS should be an adventure, not a stroll through Wonderland.   Not so with the way this was directed!!!!

Visually beautiful in Disney's simple manner. Solid performances by Storm Reid (Meg), Deric McCabe (Charles Wallace), and Chris Pine (Mr. Murray). Storm Reid, especially, is mature in her acting ability, employing finer nuances of powerful emotion in her performance. Oprah Winfrey, however, is there for name power only. She is not an actor and it shows throughout her uninspired, pandering performance. The story is, itself, inspiring and beautiful with obvious Judaeo-Christian symbolism throughout with such ideas as overcoming adversity, even evil - as well as obeying God's commands, relying upon inspiration, and turning weaknesses into strengths. Religious symbolism includes effective archetypes of the godhead and the devil, Adam & Eve, the forbidden fruit of the tree of The Knowledge of Good and Evil, the Garden of Eden and the fallen earth (I could go on) are all throughout and well used within the story. These concepts are simplified and woven into the story in a way that a full grasp of them is not necessary to appreciate the over-arching theme of good versus evil and one can enjoy the movie even if the symbolism is missed. This movie isn't polished enough to warrant a sequel. Most of the story retelling and acting is just okay - leaving the beauty solely in the hands of the over-arching story itself: which beauty, thankfuly, remains intact. A good movie to watch at home, especially with the family due to it's positive moral themes.

Considering that this is a Disney Movie I was very disappointed.  It did not have Disney Quality or Depth.  It was made more like a made for TV Movie. Oprah's performance was stale, stiff, unemotional, and unmemorable.  If she was supposed to be Glinda type guide she failed terribly.  Reese Witherspoon on the other hand, overacted, too loud, too much all around.  Mindy Kaling was dull also, seems I seen her on the cooking network.  None of them had emotional ties to their characters they were just reading a script, not performing as a character.  The little girl was OK, but she needs to be on Disney Channel for a while get some experience before taking on a movie roll.  The bright star is the little boy Deric McCabe he took on a complex role with many twists and a lot of dialog and he handled it well for such a young boy.  But he needs more experience also.   Disney needs to lock this up way in the back of the Disney Vaults.

A Wrinkle in Time has unique visuals, a good performance from its main character and can be quite moving when it wants to be. However, Ava DuVernay's take on an allegedly unfilmable book comes off as misguided thanks to overreliance on being "original", having a face-heel turn that comes out of nowhere, performances of other characters feeling like they belong in different movies and the boy from Pan having no effect on the plot. Nada. He literally just walks into the movie and accompanies our heroine and her adopted little brother because he was in the book, I guess. A Wrinkle In Time had good intentions but as far as live-action Disney movies go, this overambitious misfire is a low point for the studio.

First of all, im a 32 year old male who watched this film with his 6 year old daughter. We are both mixed race but our skin color is considered white( which matters because this movie plays like a minority empowerment film at times I don't want people to think my love for the movie has anything to do with race). I don't understand why this movie is rated badly. Yeah Oprah is in it and she's terrible, but honestly I couldn't stop crying the entire film. It's extremely metaphoric and aligns with my spiritual identity exactly.  I felt connected to the idea that love is our most important emotion and the idea of finding your true self through personal strife. I think people have taken this movie literally and missed the deep underlying point. It had my daughter and me in tears because the things they handle in the film are very real for us (abandonment, obsession with work to the point of losing family, selfishness, mistrust of others, etc.) If you are Buddhist, this movie will speak to you as it did to me. Ignore oprah and try it out.

Can a movie be as equally kooky as it is boring? This one sure is. I find myself quite astounded at how lightly fellow critics are reviewing this movie. The script of this movie appears to be written one page at a time, each by a different person and thrown together with no editing. Unashamedly I would say this might be the worst acting performance we've seen out of either Oprah Winfrey or Reese Witherspoon and it is nothing short of cringeworthy. On top of all of this, an overly ambitious attempt to create the magical dimensions described in the original book lead to some of the worst CGI production seen in a major blockbuster in quite some time. As a matter of fact, the only reason I'm not giving this film any fewer stars is due to the fact that it doesn't look like it was filmed on a handy-cam.

The special effects are beautiful but don't replace the heart of the story. The film doesn't go as deep into the darkness and terror of the It as I would have liked, but this is a children's movie so I get it. The message comes across regardless. If you loved the book as a child or are willing to watch it with childlike wonder - go for it. Especially now that it's available on Netflix.

I have not seen Selma but it got lots of praise for its acting so I have my fingers crossed that the flat script etc was more at fault than the director. Duvernay is attached to DC/Warner Bros adaptation of The New Gods, a project that has the potential to break my heart, so I want her to succeed.
Chris Pine and Gugu Mbatha-Raw, as the only adult human characters in the film, are both very good and convincing. The rest of the talented cast are not given much to do besides be cute/menacing and explain the plot. 
There is a lot of story and science removed from the source material yet it seems like there is not enough happening on screen to justify the run time. Unlike, say, the Harry Potter films there is not enough story in the book to justify the edits and Wrinkle in Time is a thin experience.

I'm awe as I read some of the reviews for A Wrinkle In Time, which I just watched again as a treat. I find it an evolved type of inspirational movie that speaks to the heart of issues faced by distinct subjects. This movie is about a tenacious, fiery, young, black girl who through nature and nurture is strong yet not allowed to show any signs of it. It;'s about self acceptance and love. Then, when I see the scenes where she's instructed to embrace herself to "tesser well" and the reminder that "aberrations are far more interesting", i'm not surprised by the widespread reaction. It's a reaction of privilege. Imagine judging the movie on the CGI, as if that ever mattered in a movie taking on such an audacious topic. Even the missing paternal figure storyline fits well with the key audience and it's even refreshing. I come out of watching it with so many positive mantras and insights and I just hope that the intended audiences are like me and never listen to the mainstream bent reviews take. Just see the movie!! It will clean the lense of self-loathing that comes standard in this universes starter-pack.

Once the movie passes the scene where they talk to the flowers (my favorite scene) it goes downhill from there. Why did Miss Whatsit turn into a giant flying leaf and fly with everyone if they truly weren't intending on seeking out the dad? Oh, because it was just meant as a visual gift for those who get distracted easily, and this movie is filled with TONS of visually amazing scenes that don't lead anywhere or are just there.

Also, whoever wrote this movie needs to understand that "intimidating" and the intellectual dialogue sounds completely absurd and silly from the mouths of children, and it also doesn't help that the child actor comes off as outright laughable when his big evil moment of stardom comes up.

I read the book when I was like 9 and remember not really understanding a lot of what was going on. I always kind of thought it was because I was only half paying attention. Watching this movie made me realize that the story was just all over the place. Things just happen, most of them seem to lack any real significance. 

Let's break one of these scenes down.The kids are taken to a magic world and ask flowers to help find their father. This makes sense. They are told to ask flowers where their father is. Weird, but sure, fine. The flowers say something in flower language, so Mrs. Whatsit turns into a giant flying lettuce leaf and carries the kids away. Oh, they must be going to find the father. A kid falls off and is caught by the flowers. Then they teleport to a completely different place. Wait...what? Why were we flying on the lettuce, if not to find the father? This kind of stuff happens repeatedly. Things that don't seem to drive the story forward, or they do, but we don't understand how or why.

There are parts of this movie that seem like they have to have been pulled directly from the book, because the writing is so atrocious on screen. I don't know how any living human being could have watched these scenes play out and not thought that they were unwatchable. Like one scene where a character goes "Charles Wallace...we're the same." and then they start multiplying small numbers by 2, therefore proving how special he is? Huh? What? These child actors too, oof. Jacob Tremblay, these kids are not.
It tries to be too "cool" and the characters are not believable.

I expected a lot from this film based on the high praise of the original work, the star power, and the promise of 21st century special effects. I was ultimately disappointed with this effort from Ava DuVernay (Selma). Admittedly, the story is one that's challenging to translate to the big screen, and even with the special effects and the contributions of Oprah Winfrey, Mindy Kaling, and Reese Witherspoon, plus Chris Pine, it just wasn't enough to make this movie more watch-able. I felt no connection to the characters; they were somehow unemotional even with all that acting. I'm not sure what the point of all this was.
I personally loved it.  If you understand energy and connecting to others, this is the perfect movie for you.

I held off seeing this in the theater because as a lover of all Madeleine L'Engle's books, the trailer for this movie left me underwhelmed. But I finally decided to give it a chance this week on Netflix. Sadly, it was even worse than I'd expected. Even with a cast of star actors, it was all just too sappy and cutesy. I'm not usually the person who complains when movies deviate from the books, as I can almost always enjoy each for their own merits. But in this case, it felt like they took the bare bones of the book and turned it into a falsely bright and goody-goody story that simply didn't do justice to the original in any fashion. Also, I'm a fan of diversity. I usually don't mind at all when directors take liberties with the source material in order to offer diverse characters. But this was...overkill. It felt like someone (the director? Disney?) was trying to make a point of checking as many cultural/ethnic boxes as possible, even changing Charles Wallace to an adopted child in order to (it felt to me) include yet another diverse character. Don't get me wrong, the little boy who played Charles Wallace was brilliant. But on top of everything else, it just felt contrived. Overall, the movie was far too floofy and sugary, like the director was afraid the source story wasn't good enough or wouldn't be appealing enough to kids and adults (never mind it's been an award-winning, bestselling classic for decades). So it had to be prettied up and made to appear visually bright and colorful and magical, like the inside of a candy store. For me...it fell flat and I came away from it thinking it was one of the worst movies I've seen in a good long time. And I think I would have felt that way even if I had never read the book.

Absolute garbage. Disney is so far out of touch with its target audience. This film panders to a liberalist audience that only supports LGBT agendas. They were more concerned in a concentrated mix of ethnicities and alternate family models to further their all inclusive ideal. The beginning of the movie seems very contrived and more concerned with an appearance of diversity than in trying to tell a story. I watch movies to escape political agendas and personal beliefs of movie executives and producers.

The book won every children's book award under the sun.  It was hailed when my children was just the age of the heroine and her guypal, though it had been pubished a decade earlier.   They did a really fine job of this I think - except that, with the topic so much about the abstract and imagination, there would always be the problem:  when we make the story a film, the imagination  of the reader is no longer included - the images are there to see, NOT imagine any longer.  A HUGE berm in the road of such a film project.           

So for 50 years there was NO movie version of this top award-winning book.    But thanks to today's neat special effects, it was not a limited experience. The visuals in the film were not disappointing.

SPOILERS BELOW. 

I didn't love the old movie as much as the book and this new remake wasn't what I wanted in a movie about this book either but I understand why they did what they did. 

First of all THERE ARE SPOILERS here so don't read from here on out if u want to watch it fresh with no spoilers and want surprises. If u I ant to want it and get angry, read the book. Wait a week. Read it again. Refer to the book often to fact check before watching it so you have it all in your head. And honestly I think he first movie was worse in comparison to the new one so if u really want to enjoy this one, watch them both so you will like Disney's new one more. Continuing on now. 

The book was amazing. I've read it perhaps six times in thirty years and don't remember but I may have done a report on it once and probably discussed the book often with other readers and peers so keep it in mind during my review. Also I have read all the books and have about decent memory if not total understandIng of the series as well so some things missing irritate me. That's a big problem I have with the new movie as well that colors my perspective. I also have a strong belief in keeping true to the original book and series when making a movie and can see reasoning as to why things were cut for production and time reasons but I don't like them and this also colors my perspective. But I will try to be fair. Here goes. 

So a lot was cut out or barely mentioned from the book in the new movie. The Jenkins arc was barely referenced and and not touched upon at all. That sucks. Time was probably the main reason, and that goes for a lot of my gripes. 

The movie had hardly no impact or reference for this being a battle for Charles Wallace's "soul" or being forced to conform to society or remain an individual. Time again probably and maybe it was too deep for a Disney movie. Disney probably didn't want the artraction of meg and Calvin as a focal point due to their ages I'd guess. I dont think Charles Wallace was adopted in the book, but it made some sense for the tension of the IT controlled kid to play into his attitude to the Dad. I'll attribute that to creative license I guess. But I think it also lessens the love of meg to Charles Wallace and that isn't my feelings of an adopted kid being loved less or anything, certainly not according to my believes or anything in my life, I'm just assuming it wasn't done to help explain the dialogue used in the movie. Opinion only as I said. 

I don't remember the dog being in any scenes but my kid said it was there somewhere so it probably wasn't but had no impact on me watching it and so time probably was the reason as we'll as the big boy being integral so there u go. Think it wasn't called fortinbras in the book and I vaguely remember hearing someone say FORT early on so okay whatever. Calvin's one or two lines about his home life in response to meg talking about why who used Calvin know about not being accepted everywhere and maybe he was only looked at as a jock to me felt overlooked and mentioned briefly as a nod to what was actually pretty important to his character background and thus making him more important to being in the film at all. Without that backstory or such I just saw him as being hungry a couple times and pretty useless in the movie except to play as a foil to meg in showing they shouldn't stay and conform on the planet with the mustached guy. Sigh. May as well have taken him completely ouT of the film without all that. Like they basically did with Jenkins. Jenkins is super important in my opinion to the story as his arc with meg and Charles giving them backstory and how they don't really fit in at school but it was all basically cut.  Time probably was the reason and they chose to focus on the rescue. 

I thought Charles was basically a recluse and mute at school in the book. Don't remember him going off like the movie had him do. I'll give it to them because it made him more attractive on screen as a good little brother and defensive of his family which made his turn against his dad when the it controlled him more impactful on the screen so I get it even though i like the book setup much more. And the teachers knowing Charles was gifted I thought was important to tell the audience in the movie since they cut out all the family interaction really so o understand it if not agree with the choice. 

I don't remember seeing the twins at all. Which in addition to all the stuff that was cut from the movie that was in the book makes me strongly believe that they have absolutely no plans on doing the other books as movies. They are sort of inportant in other books, and what interactions and dialogue that wasn't in the movie about a lot of these things make doing the sequels harder without laying the groundwork now. I really think that they should have committed more and done this as a multipart miniseries of maybe five or six hours and done it to scale and really fleshed out the entire book. If Disney got the rights just to make money on a single movie and ignore the rest, then all the cuts make sense. So in my jaded opinion they did this as a money grab and edited it down to what was integral in their timeframe and ignored the rest or made just passing reference to parts that the book used to help tell the entire story. I truly believe they just wanted to make money on a single movie and cut way too much. As a whole the book should really be told in its entirety. 

The special effects were good. Disney I think threw too much music into the score and at times it needed to be lower in volume so the dialogue was more distinct. In some cases the inpactfulness of a scene and the essential dialogue and acting was reduced by loud music and scoring. 

The story was really dumbed down for the audience, and maybe that is because it was aimed at kids and not people who know the book. He wanted to entertain and not have kids ask parents questions during the film. I'm guessing that in that vein they accomplished their goal and that wasn't meant to insult any kids or their intelligence. I feel that the book was aimed at perhaps a sixteen year old kid up to an adult in their twenties. This movie I feel was aimed at kids from ten to sixteen and if they are on the younger side obviously to be watched with their parents. Purely an opinion. I haven't any idea on how bright kids are now or what their level of understanding is. I'm going by ages of kids from my era. I am about forty years old to give you a reference point. Again, no insult intended to anyone's intelligence level is intended. I am guessing. And obviously this is a Disney movie I assume is aimed at a younger demographic. I feel they only just barely touched on meg and her faults and acceptance or embracing of such and honestly the focus of her love for (or of if u prefer) Charles Wallace was obviously there but not as impactful as in the book. Either by design or not I am not sure. It didn't seem like the major focal point or epiphany as the book intended in my opinion, because I'd think that Disney would beat you over the head with it in a movie. I appreciated it not being in a way that obviously pandered to me, but it did seem underwhelming in comparison to the book. And I don't know if I like their choice or not. 

If I'm remembering correctly, meg was at l set at one point in the book "lost" or being taken over by the IT and she needed to be brought back into "herself" for lack of a better term.  All I can find in the movie that is sort of like this is when her dad is trying to bring her back or wake her up whatever the hell was going on there. As I recall in the book, she needed to recite chemistry or math problems or something GROUNDED IN SCIENCE and her brain and memory and knowledge to recover her being. That didn't happen here. Her dad basically just called her name and shook her or something and she was back. Then he was going to leave her again (after saying minutes earlier I'd never leave you and then said he never meant to be gone so long but that has nothing to do with his original choice to actually leave her and now he's doing it again which i chuckled at after pausing the movie to point this out to my family as we were all watching it together and after thinking about it since then has made me angrier at the illogic and poor wording.). Well, the only thing close to the recovery of megs core being from the book is ironically how the IT got control of Charles Wallace in the movie. Reciting the two times table. Which is mathematics. Which in the book is a major part of what makes meg a standout if not as a student but an intelligent girl. It sort of fits the narrative the movie shows as an obvious logical pattern. The bouncing balls the kids do in the driveways and the houses and identical mothers speaking in unison. I get it. Anyone watching the movie has figured out this obvious connection. So maybe I'm not remembering the book perfectly because I was sure meg was amazing at math and reciting facts about such was how she was recovered in the book. Maybe it was chemistry which is basically just math in the number of electrons to join elements together or maybe it was her calculating pi or an equation which is not repeating or something that would stand out as a pattern but I'm pretty sure math was involved as a few of the questions either Calvin or her dad or Charles Wallace used to bring her back. And I think it happened twice actually. But the movie didn't use anything to bring her back. That pissed me off. 

Now I am almost CERTAIN there was not even a mention of a farandolae (excuse the spelling if it's off) with a name that had to bury or root itself and grow or something and it was actually inside Charles Wallace and it was the one deciding factor that would determine if he was going to go good or bad, conform or stay individual, etc. He had a name too. Now it HAS BEEN several years since I read any of the books at all so I'm going off a memory of at least a dozen years here. Maybe I'm wrong and this is from a later book. But I am pretty sure it's from WRINKLE and it was a major part of the story.  Why was this cut?  Time?  Didn't want to scare or confuse kids?  Keep focus of movie on rescuing Dad?  Too deep into science or sci-fi?  Any or all. Whatever the reason, I feel this was a tremendous loss. Didn't Megan's love of the farandolae youngster rescue him and help him root and win the battle and he helped them later?  This whole adventure near the end seemed to take place on a planet. I thought the "planet" was a short stay like a weigh station to rest up and return to the battle later when they met up with the witches again and then the entire time after was inside Charles Wallace. Was the dad inside Charles Wallace?  Not sure I remember if they rescued their dad from inside him or what in the book, but they did seem to simplify all this to not confuse the audience (I still believe it's mainly aimed at kids anyway) and removed even more science from this story. 

There's more I didn't like. I truly hated a great deal of things in the film that were either changed, dumbed down, barely referenced, or missing completely that were in the book. And this stuff happens. I get that doing this movie in full like the book would probably take twice as long. I get it. Maybe even five hours. People won't sit for that in a theater. And probably not kids. Got u. Disney HAS A NETWORK.  Maybe multiple ones I don't know. Channels. They could easily have shot this into five or so hours and cut it up into a miniseries. Show it an hour a day for five days. Or three episodes of two apiece I dunno. They could have done this I mean they have the distribution and can release a two disc set for sale as well as showing it over a couple days and advertise  it I mean they have the money airtime network distribution...they have the means. Why sacrifice so much to throw out another two hour movie and cut so much and adapt it for such a different audience???

It is an injustice to those of us that wanted to see the book fleshed out and done fully. I think they cut way too much story, arcs, and dumbed it down for a different target demographic than what the book was originally intended. For a two hour fantasy movie, I guess it was okay. They made money. I think lots of it. But this wasn't what I could or should have been and they left a lot more money on the table for future use. The other books. A longer movie replacing this also fills more airtime and builds the watching audience up begging for more. Sequels on the other books. And they could ALWAYS cut down the original long version I'd have preferred and adapted it into this film or even reshot it. Hell they could have animated this into a cartoon later or done it with the ducks like they did with the old Christmas special or even the (non-Disney) chipmunks go to the movies series they used to adapt famous movies. 

There were several options to utilize with their VAST RESOURCES that would have been superior to this movie version and they could have banked on what I listed above as spinoffs or the like AFTER doing this film. Which I'm sure they won't do. I assume they own the rights now to the book and likely the series. Why not start off with a long true to story version that's longer and uses everything in the first book and leaving the seeds for the others later down the line?  Like I said they could edit and shorten it to make a second version close to what they made, and even gone animated even for it. As is, they made a movie that is based on a good book and honestly in my opinion this was a one and done with absolutely no thought to the rest of the books. It's not as deep as the book, it's in my opinion dumbed down and devoid of the science and math and several plot points and story arcs that are needed for later, and all I see is a very base version of what could have been excellent.

There was nothing really that parents and kids could sit down with and explain afterwards or even during, certainly nothing to prompt multiple viewings to take specific note of dialogue to look deeper into the characters, and t was almost totally based on the power of love as well as accepting ones faults and loving yourself despite them. Not because of them. Not because your faults make u unique and working towards betting yourself because now you know what they are, which honestly is where I figured they would end up like an old afternoon special tv show on the weekends on abc which I think Disney owns that channel anyway, but it's a block of a couple hours that doesn't make one think nearly as much as the book and is missing way too much.

I tried to watch this movie and judge it on its own merits rather than compare it to the book I read dozens and dozens of times as a child.  To be fair, it's utterly visually stunning, which is what earned it the additional half star in this review.  But beyond that, it's an overblown yet weak plot line.  Problems that didn't need to exist in the first place are given intense focus only to have a simplistic solution.  Meg's (Storm Reid) awkwardness is forced and never really fleshed out beyond some mean girls teasing her about her father being gone.  The scene where the kids get to Camazotz and are told "don't let anything split you up", but then Charles Wallace (Deric McCabe) is immediately separated from them is a giant, gaping plot contradiction.  I know this movie was lauded for casting women of color in the leading roles, but in this venue it loses the impact it could have made.  And the final message of "no Meg, it was all about you" is trite and disjointed, suitable for something other than a story witih a science fiction core.

Now, to compare it to the book, it failied.  Miserably and utterly failed.  To start, the setting is completely off.  This is supposed to take place in a small town in New England where gossip and narrow-mindedness reign supreme, not the suburbs of Los Angeles.  Reese Witherspoon's portrayal of Mrs. Whatsit is completely WRONG.  She is critical and harsh where in the book, Mrs. Whatsit is loving, kind, and sweet.  I would have rather seen Witherspoon switch places with Winfrey, since Mrs. Which is supposed to be the harsh, cold one of the trio.  In the book, Camazotz is all about conformity.  The scene of the children with the balls is (mostly) correct, but from there they go into a faceless city and then enter Central central.  The beach scene just indicates to me that Ava DuVernay didn't understand the nature of Camazotz, or the natures of either the man with the red eyes OR Charles Wallace.  What's even more unfortunate is that Calvin (Levi Miller) is brought along for "his diplomacy" which the movie then never even attempts to use.  That's not even mentioning how badly his character has been watered down.  In the books, Calvin is beaten *because* he gets high grades and is incredibly intelligent, far more so than his half-dozen brothers and sisters.  He comes across Meg and Charles Wallace as he's trying to escape a household full of anger and stress.  This movie turns him into nothing more than just another kid with an overbearing, authoritative father yelling at him for getting "ok" grades.  And in the book, Meg doesn't just throw a ball at another girl, she punches the nose of a boy twice her size.  To me, that would have been much more empowering and indicative of standing up to a bully.

I don't expect any movie to be a true representation of the book.  The only one I've found that came close was "The Shawshank Redemption".  But this was nothing more than some fanciful excuse to use big names in a lot of CGI while only maybe touching base with the book now and then.  There have got to be scores of other pre-teen books they could have used, they didn't have to ruin one of my childhood favorites.

- A Wrinkle in Time sparkles with fresh life and girl power -

Time for another full disclosure: I've been worried about whether A Wrinkle in Time was going to be good.

All the ingredients were right. I'm a sold-out fangirl for director Ava DuVernay (Selma, 13TH). I adore that finally, FINALLY a major fantasy novel adaptation stars people of color. And of course, I always get jazzed about a new book-to-movie adventure!

But there was much to make me nervous. As much as I love Ava, she'd never made a kids movie before. Disney has quite the reputation for throwing money at big, splashy, colorful projects that turn out to be empty and frankly headache-inducing. Not to mention it's hard to turn a beloved book into a movie that everyone actually thinks is good!

So I got my ticket and tried to measure my expectations.

And you know? A Wrinkle in Time is weird. It's surprising. Some scenes are big and splashy, and some are shockingly intimate. Right now it's actually scoring pretty low on review sites like IMDB and Rotten Tomatoes. But screw those guys. I liked it.

From the moment that Mrs. Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon, Home Again), garbed beautifully in stolen bedsheets, flashed her eyes, proclaimed "Wild nights are my glory!" and ran into the stormy evening, I was sold.

A quick recap for the new kids: A Wrinkle in Time is a kids book written in the 1950's about a girl named Meg Murray, her family, and the neighbor boy Calvin. It's a great romp about dimensions colliding in a fight for good and evil. The kids must team up with new supernatural friends to traverse galaxies and rescue Meg's father, a great scientist, who has been trapped by an evil power. It nearly didn't get published because it was so odd - and I love that the movie carries that same spirit.

It's humorous and self-aware at unexpected moments. The brother-sister team played by Storm Reid (12 Years a Slave) as Meg and Deric McCabe (Stephanie) as Charles Wallace are so charming and fresh, but more complex than your average kid characters. The grand, celestial beings called "The Mrs.'s" - played by Witherspoon, Mindy Kaling (Why Not Me?), and Oprah Winfrey (The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks) aren't just powerful and majestic. They are quirky, funny, and irreverent (just like they are in the boooooook!).

In fact, the movie goes for interesting, gutsy contradictions. I'm not used to the sight of warriors dressed in avant garde gowns and glittery makeup. I don't typically find movies where the hero discovers victory in her faults, instead of her strengths. And I certainly don't often watch kids stories where parents and their children square up so openly and brazenly about their vulnerabilities and hurts.

Truthfully, this movie would never have been created in another era. For the first time, a Black woman stands at the helm of a $100+ million live-action project. And as she always does, Ms. DuVernay "demand[ed] inclusiveness," according to Witherspoon, leading to diversity in both the cast and the crew.

Today is a day to be excited as movies led by Black women become runaway box-office hits. 2018 is a year to be proud of the slow fade of girl-characters in movies who look to their male companions and ask (wide eyed) "What do we do now?" Not Meg. And not in Ava's movies.

A Wrinkle in Time does have its weak points, for sure. Some melodrama can definitely be found coming from certain corners. Jennifer Lee (Frozen) and Jeff Stockwell's (Bridge to Terabithia) script, while strong in parts, sometimes fumbles. And, in the way of adaptations, the movie does sacrifice some important content from the book. But oh, Ava is so loving with her camera. The way she shoots her beloved cast takes the movie a step above what the script alone could have done.

There's no doubt that the people who made A Wrinkle in Time had a deep tenderness for their project, and for the novel itself. So many lines and homages are straight from the book, and watching it actually gave me the same feeling I got from reading it. The same kind of laughs and squirms, the same magical, empowering goodness.

Take your kid, your buddy, your mom, or even just yourself to see this movie. Because this is one kids movie truly made with enough heart, wonder, and delight to rise above its faults. Just like Meg.

----------

This review was first published on Narrative Muse, http://www.narrativemuse.co/movies/a-wrinkle-in-time, and was written by Debbie Holloway. Narrative Muse curates the best books and movies by and about women and non-binary folk on our website http://narrativemuse.co and our social media channels.

The cast of this movie was the best thing about it, it was visually beautiful at times, but had so many plot holes I felt like I was watching with one eye closed. Unfortunately the story is disjointed and leaves too much unexplained, and Reese Witherspoon's sickeningly sweet Miss What'sit comes across as so insincere, you start to wonder if she is on the evil side. With it's commentary on social norms, violence, and religion this is hardly a family flick. Extremely disturbing visuals and emotionally traumatic dialogue make this film that was advertised as a family fun adventure fall extremely flat in my personal opinion. To summarize I've rarely watched a family film with a great cast and been left feeling this gross. I gave one star for Chris Pine in his role as the father, he was brilliant as always the rest of the actors were victims of bad script. Spare yourselves.

Nobody bats 1.000.  Based on the beloved fantasy novel, this is about a young girl named Meg (Storm Reid).  Her scientist father (Chris Pine) has been missing for some time, and three mysterious beings appear to assist her in traveling through time and space to recover him.  Now I know how dearly some people hold this book to their hearts.  I am not in that camp because I've never read it.  Maybe I chose something else off of the required summer reading list, or maybe I was just sick that week.  The one thing I did hear people say about this is that it is unfilmable.  This obviously didn't stop Disney from trying... twice.  I am of the mindset that not everything calls for a cinematic interpretation, and even without reading the book, I think this would have been far better off left on the page.  Now given that I do keep my ear to the ground about movies that get released, I was naturally prepared for this to be a train wreck.  I never want to have a bad time with a movie, so I tried to approach this with an open mind.  It was very apparent very early on that everything about this falls flat, and I am struggling to come up with nice things to say about A Wrinkle in Time.  This is a story that is supposed to fill you with wonder.  That never once happens here, and it just ends up being bland fantasy.  The script is pretty weak all things considered, and I had an awfully difficult time giving this my undivided attention at home where I could be making a better use of my time.  None of the actors are ever able to sell it despite earnest efforts, and this has everything to do with the story requiring the child actors do most of the heavy lifting.  I think Storm Reid does have potential, and she is certainly leaps and bounds above the other two lead kids, but she can only do so much with her limited experience.  There is nothing about this movie that gels together with cohesion.  The science behind it all seems to work or not work depending on when the script calls for it, and it really just ends up being an adult looking at children saying, "that will/won't work right now".  When that is the forward movement of the story, you can just poke holes in every contrived plot point.  Whenever I started to get into this, I got yanked back out by some pop song that they are trying to sell, and A Wrinkle in Time is as botched as advertised.

I was so very wary of watching this movie, and my instincts proved right. This  movie is so far from how I envisioned the story from reading the book when it first came out - yeah, I'm that old. 

Maybe how you picture "A Wrinkle in Time" depends on how old you were when you read it, and when. 

This was a book of its time. Even being 8 years old, I knew that part of the shadow of darkness was communism. We had civil defense drills and a missile crises, and we all KNEW that the worst evil we could think of was having the US turn into a Soviet state. Or be like East Germany. Or China. Or Cuba.

 No freedom of thought or action, a "big brother" (IT) overseeing all of us all the time, and having to comply and conform totally. And no religion allowed (we were told to bury our Bibles to hide them). So that was Camozotz for me - a world like our own - not a magic planet with tornadoes and folding-up houses - that had given in to the darkness of totalitarianism. Where you couldn't be different - have faults like Meg - or love your family - or worship a higher being. It was a scary time - could there be a Mrs. Who or Which or Whatsit to help keep away the darkness? I actually pictured part of the book in black and white - that was what television was, right? - and re-read the book again when a few years later I saw Richard Burton's movie (black & white) of "The Spy Who Came in from the Cold". East Berlin = death and darkness.

So....what to make of the recent "A Wrinkle in Time" movie? It's sure pretty - and the message to be yourself and appreciate what you are because you're wonderfully unique - can't hurt. But the movie's just too bright and bouncy and fluffy - like cotton candy. The Mrs.s? In our world they were ugly witch stereotypes (to contrast to their latter gloriousness) - and you had to battle HARD and maybe suffer to fight the darkness - and it was Meg's offering of unconditional love for Charles Wallace - as awful as he was - that saved them -NOT Meg concentrating on how much she was loved - though the statement that Mrs. Whatsit didn't love her was IT's mistake. 

For me, this movie ISN'T "A Wrinkle in Time" - it's a feel-good, positive message to kids movie, and an opportunity to travel the universe with some dang beautiful ladies.

A Wrinkle in Time definitely has its silly moments, some ridiculous characters, it's weakly directed and the entire second act is rather messy in execution. However, the first act is very strong as is the moving third act, the special effects are excellent, the characters are quite well developed, the theme of self-acceptance is well explored and the acting is pretty good with the highlights being Chris Pine and also Storm Reid who showed a lot of promise here with a stupendous performance. It is a flawed, but definitely solid adaptation of a basically unfilmable novel and thus quite underappreciated as it is nowhere near as bad as many would say.

I've never read the book, so I can't speak to how well it follows that series. The movie itself was just very fast-paced, non-linear, and hard to follow. Just seemed like when putting scenes of the movie together they didn't really care about transitioning from one event to the next.

Well, it's heart is in the right place-unfortunately, little else fits together in this confused, if sincere and kind, effort. Stiff acting, atrocious writing, needlessly flashy camerawork, low energy music, but at least with a loving aim. Yet in the end, that emotional purity works against itself: There is absolutely no conflict for long stretches, just people immediately consenting to one another, never struggling, barely butting heads, until an overwrought climax where all the emotional and narrative friction explodes in a risible farce-and, worse still, to what end? The world is better off not materially, but spiritually, which ironically enough, in this instance, means superficially, not with any real depth. Meh.

I desperately wanted to fall in love with this movie, as a fan of the book series I thought doing so would be cake.  My hopes were dashed severely when I saw every letter of Madeleine L'engle's epic turned into a garish and incomprehensible gruel.  Where to begin but with Disney's "perfect" entertainment mecca;  they in truth are great at taking ideas that the huddled masses swoon over and making them into addictive, vacuous cash cows, but when it comes to developing complex and cerebral ideas the are light years behind.  This is exemplified by the fact that they couldn't make 5th grade required reading into an at least passable film.  On to the composition of the film itself acting, framing, tone, dialogue, special effects, sound design, soundtrack, pacing, and anything else i missed; all ugly, confused, pretentious, and boring.   Madeleine L'engle deserved better than the likes of Disney defiling a literary work that changes so many lives.  Stick with your empty worlds of static, safe, PC totalitarianism and leave art to people who want to do it justice not make another marketing campaign for fan boys to mindlessly drool over.

A massive waste of great talent and sacks of money, A Wrinkle In Time has been rightfully praised for the diversity of its cast, both in terms of gender and race, but the film in which these steps have been taken is such a let-down that they're rendered completely moot. It's clear that 10 times more effort, and cash, has been spent on the special effect than the script and the story. The entire enterprise, while looking incredible, is clumsily plotted and emotionally ineffectual. Ava DuVernay hammers in the sentimental moments but does very little to make us care about the characters, and seems more concerned with getting us to the next flashy set piece than creating an interesting story. To be fair, there's not a lot you could do with a script this cliched and banal, featuring a tonne of bland platitudes and uninteresting conflicts. The story is utterly nonsensical, and the rules seem to be made up as the film go along, and even though it doesn't have enough time to make the characters engaging, it does have enough time to turn to Reese Witherspoon into a Pok√©mon and have her fly around a planet for several minutes. It should be noted that nothing is accomplished while on this planet, and they then travel a place to consult a character who advises them where to go next. Shouldn't that have been the first place they went? It's best not to think too hard about it; the filmmakers clearly didn't, and I'm not even remotely surprised that it flopped at the box office. It's all well and good having your movie celebrate diversity and equality, but if your film fails then your message will fail, and A Wrinkle In Time has nothing to say that a million other movies hasn't said already.

I knew this movie would be nothing like the book based on the trailers, but it was so completely off-course I could barely recognize the book I loved from my childhood at all.  The casting was great and one of the only redeeming qualities was the superb acting by everyone involved, especially the children.  They all did the best they could with what they had to work with, but the story was a mess.  I understand why they did away with the flat planet and my beloved Aunt Beast (although they oddly mentioned her name in a passing image of where the father had been).  The whole thing just seemed like an excuse to use a bunch of over-the-top and unnecessary special effects.  But the story moved too slowly.  It was boring, despite the stunning visuals.  I just couldn't figure out why so much was changed from the book for no apparent reason.  It seems like they could have at least tried to make an adaptation of the book and deviated where needed, rather than make this completely different story that only vaguely resembled the original.  Just so disappointed after waiting practically my whole life for this movie.

Not only is the movie unbearable to look at it was also incredibly difficult to listen to with grotesquely mainstream "feel good" music and badly delivered lines accompanied with bizarre unnatural dialogue, with characters explaining the story at every turn of events. Hopefully my decision to walk out about half way through will counter my idiotic decision to pay $14 for a ticket to this absolute shit show.

The reviews were not great for "A Wrinkle in Time" and I honestly understand some of the issues that people had with it.  The story definitely has some problems when it concerns development, pacing and establishment but the positives this film brings allowed me to overlook these problems.  What this movie does well-exceptionally well-is in the performances, the visuals and its heart.  The entire cast is just absolutely stellar and the visuals are beautiful to look at from beginning to end.  My favorite aspect, however, proved to be the drama and emotions it delivered.  I'll put it bluntly, the film was a tear-jerker but beautiful in the way it delivered it.  A lot of it hit too close to home for my comfort but I found it to be a tremendous experience despite its flaws.

Based on the much loved children's book of the same name, "A Wrinkle in Time" carries a great sense of wonder and awe bought towards it's narrative, even with a great sense of visual flare to go along with it's gifted performers the film is very watchable to all viewers or especially it's target audience (family/kids). However, despite the eye-catching gazes and genuine sense of otherworldly surrealism that perpetuates the hearts and minds of all audiences, it's neither a great film within itself, nor is it a great adaptation. This doesn't just account to how many liberties were taken in the adaptation process, but more within the overall story itself. It's perfectly elaborate scale and heart-warming messages kind of want to offer more than what was briefly glimpsed at or even explored in the overall narrative that would have benefited the overarching style of this film willing to be both faithful to it's source material counterpart and creative piece of family-friendly Disney-esque surreal cinema. Thus the overall film offers a decent viewing experience for it's moral/themes and sense of adventure, but doesn't fulfill the greater aspect of it's ambitions nor it's tremendous world-building mechanics to really be very measurable to it's source material counterpart. Recommended with caution nonetheless, especially to those within it's target audience.

I am sure most of the negative reviews come from people whose love for the original novel has blinded them to the really good work Ava DuVernay put on screen. Her emphasis on color (in all senses of the word) makes this movie a visual feast. What gets lost, however, is any depth or originality to the characters. Reese Witherspoon's Mrs. Whatsit is perhaps the most whimsical, but apart from her, the lack of subtlety leaves much to be desired from older audiences. Perhaps the least subtle aspect of the film is OPRAH as Mrs.Which, whose literal gigantic presence on screen only serves to magnify the silliness of worshiping at the altar of OPRAH.  The visuals are wonderful, and the acting by most everyone is very good (despite the characters not having that much to do in the movie). With the elimination of a key section from the book, the movie runs *extremely* short, making it seem like there really wasn't that much at stake.

The movie was, frankly, bipolar. Is it a story about a child hero in a fantasy movie, which it failed at, or a social commentary, which has no place in a children's movie? No one wants the latter. The 2004 version is actually better.

The critics are missing the point:  this film is about not listening to the negative critics in your head or out of them--the message is strong: treating each other with kindness and good intent draws us away from the destructive forces of negativity, self-doubt, and self-hatred. Don't believe everything you think, and if you're a critic, don't say everything you believe. If you're a parent, bring your 9-13 year old kids--it will inoculate them against the meanies. If you're an adult, bring your inner child and remember what it's like to give in to fantasy--it's a hard book to bring to screen but a great message. Suspend your judgment, forget that "the book doesn't have that scene" and believe that you can make a difference by choosing to support, rather than tear down those who have the courage to try.

I would not recommend reading the books close to viewing the movie.  The way the film deviates from some of the more endearing aspects of the book makes it difficult to enjoy since every comparison reflects negatively on the movie.  The development of the characters and what makes them unique in the book never translates to the movie, nor does the true conflict.  

The book's setting, so crucial to the movement of the plot, is changed completely as Meg lives on a street with close neighbors rather than in the house in a field with a low rotck wall and the star-gazing rock (without reading the first book, you can't understand the significance of this setting and what it brings to the original story).  The movie felt rushed and full of boring scenes that merely forced the plot along without the extra details that were the true meat of the books.  It felt like too many corners were cut and I was watching a bare-bones summary of the book rather than an adaptation of it.  Everything that explained the mixture of science and magic in the book was omitted from the film, rendering it implausible and incoherent. Such a disappointment.

I... kind of hated this film, and I feel bad saying that as there are not a lot of films I end up actively disliking upon viewing them.  "It was different from the book" is no excuse because it's a film adaptation and some of the best adaptations I've seen take the heart and SPIRIT of a book without strictly following it line to line! This film, however, does the opposite--it removes the best parts of the book and keeps the most weak parts, adding to the weakness and even dragging it out.

You know the "happy medium" that has been pretty universally terrible in every version? Well the actor himself is thankfully more tolerable here but I hope you enjoy watching people struggle to stand on one foot for half an hour (this scene drags on and onnnnnn). Similarly, the magical creature ride on the first planet they get to... in the book at least they had a reason for the ride, to see the darkness and watch light literally fight it off giving you further insight into what sort of wonderous creatures the 3 lady's are and how important the battle is... in the film that is ALL gone and you're left with less than stellar CGI with our characters stupidly grinning in "wonder", omg, how magical! Except we're flying for no reason. And there's an action sequence because we were dumb, and that's REALLY what I wanted to see-- Our characters (who are all supposed to be extremely smart) doing STUPID things.

I'm going to have to bullet point the rest of this because I have so many complaints:

* The witches are introduced and are stunning and beautiful the entire film. This is a problem because they're supposed to be seen as quirky homeless-types at the start (the sort of person you might genuinely be concerned your 7 year old is talking to) which makes their later glory/wisdom all the more surprising and meaningful.
* Talking/moving flowers. Puke.
* Calvin is useless in this film. The actor does fine (though all he really has to do is smile and praise our protagonist at weird moments). I would have cut film Calvin entirely, he contributes nothing plot-wise or theme-wise.
* Meg is not portrayed as actually smart, she's just a normal high schooler dealing with the stereotypical high school bully problems. Charles Wallace isn't smart either--but they TALK about how smart he is and we see him drawing so that must mean he's smart, right?! No, that just means he likes doodling like every other kid.
* Bouncing ball Camazotz  scene: not terrible, actually. But it could have been a lot more unnerving and creepy. It was way too short and transitioned into my next complaint--
* Beach scene. What the actual heck. Charles Wallace just gets brainwashed... because. Why not  In the book he gets taken control of because he CHOOSES to go to IT, his hubris and feelings of superiority gets the best of him and leads to his downfall. So much more interesting than "number number, okay, I'm bad now for no reason."
* Meg and her father. I admit that I loved the scene of them reuniting, that was well acted and sweet. But god almighty the movie deliberately chose not to address him leaving Charles Wallace behind and Meg being furious at him because of it. In fact, Meg isn't given a moment of bravery and sacrifice CHOOSING to return alone to try and save her brother, instead she just screams and refuses to get whisked away in the first place. Look, I get time restrictions and all but couldn't you have cut 10 minutes of rock balancing and green creature flying to actually give our characters a meaningful arc?

A LOT of liberties were taken with the source material, and ultimately there was only one of them that I would be willing to say "Okay, that was different, but it wasn't clearly worse in every way" (that being the Happy Medium). The movie lingers on scenes that should have been  much shorter if not cut entirely. I can forgive the omission of Meg's older brothers but reducing Aunt Beast's entire species to a three second cameo is just intolerable.

Disney's latest live-action outing is a dimension-traversing trip that centres on troubled 13-year-old Meg (Storm Reid), as she journeys into the unknown to find her scientist father (Chris Pine) who disappeared four years earlier. Joined by her precocious whizz-kid brother Charles Wallace (Deric McCabe) and cute-guy-next-door Calvin (Levi Miller), our headstrong but vulnerable protagonist must confront both evil otherworldly forces and her own life-blocking emotions. Aiming to be accessible for younger audiences, the core message - internal growth is impossible without self-belief - is hardly new, but, despite a completely on-the-nose delivery, it's also effective. The connective tissue isn't always the best (the less time spent thinking about plot machinations the better), though there's no shortage of thrills and wonder, or heart wrenching payoffs, in the numerous high-concept set pieces. There are parts of this movie that are unintentionally silly and a few of director Ava DuVerney's stylistic choices are dubious (over-sized Oprah Winfrey? standard black-tentacle incarnation of 'evil'?), yet enough goodwill is generated elsewhere to forgive these missteps. DuVerney doesn't hide her influences either, family classics such as Avatar and Wizard of Oz are obvious touchstones whilst more adult-leaning masterpieces like 2001: A Space Odyssey and even The Exorcist ("Charles Wallace is not at home right now") provide inspiration. Reid is an absolute gem in the lead role too, equally convincing in her self-destructive stubbornness to detach from the world as she is in the gradual shift to valuing her strengths, weaknesses and everything in between. She feels right at home sharing the big screen with Hollywood veterans such as Reese Witherspoon and Oprah Winfrey, who, along with comedian Mindy Kaling, play an amusing trio of peculiar beings that guide our heroes on their trek. Ambitious to a fault, A Wrinkle in Time is a family-friendly fantasy saga that wears its heart on its sleeve whilst delivering a visually wondrous, if occasionally scatty, rollercoaster ride.

Disney Channel meets The View.  Insufferable platitudes about the light and the dark and personal empowerment woven through a never-ending series of special effects, sprinked with a cringe-worthy way-too-young love affair, all created in the service of a feminist agenda.  The perfect storm for a move that you have to work hard to sit all the way through.  Oprah can't act to save her life, but her performance is Oscar-worthy compared to Mindy Kaling's, which has all the dynamic expression of a wet log.  The director somehow even managed to drag all the personality out of Zach Galifianakis.  As in all the feminist propoganda movies of late, the movie culminates in the father figure apologizing for his abandonment, even though in the book he did no such thing.  Take a pass on this train wreck of a movie.

While it wasn't the most compelling adaptation of the book, there was a lot of good going on in this film. As many have said, it was visually stunning. That's a given. The message was a great one, and one worth remembering whether you're a kid or an adult.
